intro.title: Nearly 20% of the world's population will be at-risk for floods by 2050
intro.text: Forests are a natural, cost-effective way to secure ample, clean water and to protect against natural disasters like floods and droughts.

slides.title: Water
slides.subtitle: Pristine state
slides.text: Forests are critical to supplying clean and plentiful water around the world. Healthy forests filter water, reduce erosion, regulate rainfall, recharge groundwater tables and buffer against the impacts of droughts and floods. Coastal forests are especially important in providing protection from surges and are crucial breeding grounds for marine life.

slides.title: Water
slides.subtitle: Drivers of change
slides.text: Deforestation compromises watershed health and increases risk of floods and drought. More frequent and severe forest fires, exacerbated by climate change, can pollute water supplies, reduce forest cover and devastate communities.

slides.title: Water
slides.subtitle: Compromised state
slides.text: Deforested watersheds are unable to properly filter water and regulate water supply for the communities that depend on them. Erosion, flood and landslide risks increase without forests to hold sediment in place and channel precipitation under ground. Deforested coasts are more vulnerable to storm surges and fisheries suffer.

slides.title: Water
slides.subtitle: Recovery state
slides.text: Restoring and conserving forests can help increase water security. There's a growing wave of investments in forests for water, given the economic, environmental and public health benefits these critical lands can generate.
